id.desc: Component ID, not specified by default. If specified, it can be used to refer the component in option or API.

name.desc:
Series name used for displaying in [tooltip][0] and filtering with [legend][1], or updating data and configuration with setOption.

[0]: #tooltip
[1]: #legend

colorBy.desc:
>  Since > v5.2.0 The policy to take color from [option.color][0]. Valid values: 

* 'series': assigns the colors in the palette by series, so that all data in the same series are in the same color;
* 'data': assigns colors in the palette according to data items, with each data item using a different color.



[0]: #color

coordinateSystem.desc:
The coordinate used in the series, whose options are: 

* 'cartesian2d' Use a two-dimensional rectangular coordinate (also known as Cartesian coordinate), with [xAxisIndex][0] and [yAxisIndex][1] to assign the corresponding axis component.

* 'polar' Use polar coordinates, with [polarIndex][2] to assign the corresponding polar coordinate component.



[0]: #series-bar.xAxisIndex
[1]: #series-bar.yAxisIndex
[2]: #series-bar.polarIndex

xAxisIndex.desc:
Index of [x axis][0] to combine with, which is useful for multiple x axes in one chart.

[0]: #xAxis

yAxisIndex.desc:
Index of [y axis][0] to combine with, which is useful for multiple y axes in one chart.

[0]: #yAxis

polarIndex.desc:
Index of [polar coordinate][0] to combine with, which is useful for multiple polar axes in one chart.

[0]: #polar

symbol.desc:
Symbol of . Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

If symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format: 

    (value: Array|number, params: Object) => string
    

The first parameter value is the value in [data][1], and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData
[1]: #series-line.data

symbolSize.desc:
symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10. If size of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format: 

    (value: Array|number, params: Object) => number|Array
    

The first parameter value is the value in [data][0], and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

[0]: #series-line.data

symbolRotate.desc:
Rotate degree of symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle. If rotation of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format: 

    (value: Array|number, params: Object) => number
    

The first parameter value is the value in [data][0], and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item. 

> Callback is supported since 4.8.0 . 

[0]: #series-line.data

symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

symbolOffset.desc: Offset of symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value. For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

showSymbol.desc: Whether to show symbol. It would be shown during tooltip hover.

showAllSymbol.desc:
Only work when main axis is 'category' axis (axis.type is 'category'). Optional values: 

* 'auto': Default value. Show all symbols if there is enough space. Otherwise follow the interval strategy with with [axisLabel.interval][0].
* true: Show all symbols.
* false: Follow the interval strategy with [axisLabel.interval][0].



[0]: #xAxis.axisLabel.interval

legendHoverLink.desc:
Whether to enable highlighting chart when [legend][0] is being hovered.

[0]: #legend

stack.desc:
If stack the value. On the same category axis, the series with the same stack name would be put on top of each other. The effect of the below example could be seen through stack switching of [toolbox][0] on the top right corner: 暂时无法显示

[0]: #toolbox

cursor.desc: The mouse style when mouse hovers on an element, the same as cursor property in CSS.

connectNulls.desc: Whether to connect the line across null points.

clip.desc:
>  Since > v4.4.0 If clip the overflow on the coordinate system. Clip results varies between series: 

* Scatter/EffectScatter：Ignore the symbols exceeds the coordinate system. Not clip the elements.
* Bar：Clip all the overflowed. With bar width kept.
* Line：Clip the overflowed line.
* Lines: Clip all the overflowed.
* Candlestick: Ignore the elements exceeds the coordinate system.
* Custom: Clip all the olverflowed.

All these series have default value true except custom series. Set it to false if you don't want to clip.

step.desc: Whether to show as a step line. It can be true, false. Or 'start', 'middle', 'end'. Which will configure the turn point of step line. See the example using different step options: 暂时无法显示

label.desc: Text label of , to explain some data information about graphic item like value, name and so on. label is placed under itemStyle in ECharts 2.x. In ECharts 3, to make the configuration structure flatter, labelis taken to be at the same level with itemStyle, and has emphasis as itemStyle does.

label.position.desc:
Label position. **Followings are the options:*** [x, y] Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example: 

      // Absolute pixel values
      position: [10, 10],
      // Relative percentage
      position: ['50%', '50%']
* 'top'
* 'left'
* 'right'
* 'bottom'
* 'inside'
* 'insideLeft'
* 'insideRight'
* 'insideTop'
* 'insideBottom'
* 'insideTopLeft'
* 'insideBottomLeft'
* 'insideTopRight'
* 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/view.html?c=doc-example/label-position

label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element. It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight'). See: [label position][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=doc-example/label-position

label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise. See: [label rotation][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=bar-label-rotation

label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

label.color.desc: text color. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

label.borderDashOffset.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example: 

* padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
* padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
* padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

label.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

label.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

label.textBorderColor.desc: Storke color of the text. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

label.textBorderWidth.desc: Storke line width of the text.

label.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With textBorderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    textBorderType: [5, 10],
    
    textBorderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

label.textBorderDashOffset.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

label.textShadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text itself.

label.textShadowBlur.desc: Shadow blue of the text itself.

label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

endLabel.valueAnimation.desc: Whether to enable text animation of value change.

labelLine.show.desc: Whether to show the label guide line.

labelLine.showAbove.desc: Whether to show the label guide line above the corresponding element.

labelLine.length2.desc: The length of the second segment of guide line.

labelLine.smooth.desc: Whether to smooth the guide line. It defaults to be false and can be set as true or the values from 0 to 1 which indicating the smoothness.

labelLine.minTurnAngle.desc: Minimum turn angle between two segments of guide line to prevent unaesthetic display when angle is too small. Can be 0 - 180 degree.

labelLine.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color. 

> Supports setting as solid color using > rgb(255,255,255)> , > rgba(255,255,255,1)> , > #fff> , etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [> option.color][0]>  for details 

[0]: #color

labelLine.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With dashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    type: [5, 10],
    
    dashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

The style of the decal pattern. It works only if [aria.enabled][0] and [aria.decal.show][1] are both set to be true. If it is set to be 'none', no decal will be used. It works only if areaStyle is set.

[0]: #aria.enabled
[1]: #aria.decal.show

itemStyle.decal.symbol.desc:
The symbol type of the decal. If it is in the type of string[], it means the symbols are used one by one. Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData

itemStyle.decal.symbolSize.desc: Range of values: 0 to 1, representing the size of symbol relative to decal.

itemStyle.decal.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether or not to keep the aspect ratio of the pattern.

itemStyle.decal.color.desc: For the color of the decal pattern, it is recommended to use a translucent color, which can be superimposed on the color of the series itself.

itemStyle.decal.backgroundColor.desc: The background color of the decal will be over the color of the series itself, under the decal pattern.

itemStyle.decal.dashArrayX.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved. dashArrayX controls the horizontal pattern pattern. When its value is of type number or number[], it is similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray][0]. 

* If it is of type number, it means that the pattern and the blank space are of this value respectively. For example, 5 means the pattern with width 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with width 5 is displayed...
* In the case of number[] type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of an array of values. For example: [5, 10, 2, 6] means the pattern is 5 pixels wide, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels wide, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels wide...
* If of type (number | number[])[], it means that each row is a loop with an array of values for the pattern and blank space. For example: [10, [2, 5]] means that the first line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space, the second line will be 2 pixels by 2 pixels and empty space, and the third line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples. 暂时无法显示

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

itemStyle.decal.dashArrayY.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved. dashArrayY controls the horizontal pattern pattern. Similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray][0]. 

* If it is a number type, it means the pattern and the blank are each of this value. For example, 5 means that the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed...
* In the case of number[] type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of sequential array values. For example: [5, 10, 2, 6] means the pattern is 5 pixels high, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels high, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels high...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples. 暂时无法显示

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

itemStyle.decal.maxTileWidth.desc: The upper limit of the width of the generated pattern before it is duplicated. Usually this value is not necessary, but you can try to increase it if you notice discontinuous seams in the pattern when it repeats.

itemStyle.decal.maxTileHeight.desc: The upper limit of the height of the generated pattern before it repeats. This value is usually not necessary to set, but you can try to increase it if you find that the pattern has discontinuous seams when it is repeated.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.shadowOffse.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

emphasis.itemStyle.color.desc:
color. Since 5.2.0, it can be set to 'inherit' in the emphasis state to disable color highlight. 

> Supports setting as solid color using > rgb(255,255,255)> , > rgba(255,255,255,1)> , > #fff> , etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [> option.color][0]>  for details 

[0]: #color

emphasis.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

emphasis.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc: border width. No border when it is set to be 0. border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

emphasis.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

emphasis.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

emphasis.endLabel.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

emphasis.endLabel.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

emphasis.endLabel.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

emphasis.endLabel.rich.<style_name>.widt.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

emphasis.endLabel.rich.<style_name>.heig.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

blur.label.position.desc:
Label position. **Followings are the options:*** [x, y] Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example: 

      // Absolute pixel values
      position: [10, 10],
      // Relative percentage
      position: ['50%', '50%']
* 'top'
* 'left'
* 'right'
* 'bottom'
* 'inside'
* 'insideLeft'
* 'insideRight'
* 'insideTop'
* 'insideBottom'
* 'insideTopLeft'
* 'insideBottomLeft'
* 'insideTopRight'
* 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/view.html?c=doc-example/label-position

blur.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element. It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight'). See: [label position][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=doc-example/label-position

blur.label.rotate.desc:

>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

Shadow Y offset of the text block.

blur.endLabel.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

blur.endLabel.rich.<style_name>.height.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

select.label.position.desc:
Label position. **Followings are the options:*** [x, y] Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example: 

      // Absolute pixel values
      position: [10, 10],
      // Relative percentage
      position: ['50%', '50%']
* 'top'
* 'left'
* 'right'
* 'bottom'
* 'inside'
* 'insideLeft'
* 'insideRight'
* 'insideTop'
* 'insideBottom'
* 'insideTopLeft'
* 'insideBottomLeft'
* 'insideTopRight'
* 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position][0].

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

select.labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

select.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

select.labelLine.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

select.labelLine.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

select.labelLine.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

* 'break' Break by word

select.endLabel.lineOverflow.desc:

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

select.endLabel.rich.<style_name>.shadow.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

select.endLabel.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

select.endLabel.rich.<style_name>.height.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

selectedMode.desc: >  Since > v5.0.0 Selected mode. It is enabled by default, and you may set it to be false to disabled it. Besides, it can be set to 'single' or 'multiple', for single selection and multiple selections.

smooth.desc:
Whether to show as smooth curve. If is typed in boolean, then it means whether to enable smoothing. If is typed in number, valued from 0 to 1, then it means smoothness. A smaller value makes it less smooth. Please refer to [smoothMonotone][0] to change smoothing algorithm.

[0]: #series-line.smoothMonotone

smoothMonotone.desc:
Whether the broken line keep the monotonicity when it is smoothed. It can be set as 'x', 'y' to keep the monotonicity on x axis or y axis. It is usually used on dual value axis. Here are 2 examples of broken line chart with dual value axis, showing the differences when smoothMonotone is without any setting, and smoothMonotone is set as 'x'. 

* No setting about smoothMonotone:

![][0]

* It is set as 'x':

![][1]



[0]: documents/asset/img/smooth-monotone-none.png
[1]: documents/asset/img/smooth-monotone-x.png

sampling.desc:
The dowmsampling strategy used when the data size is much larger than pixel size. It will improve the performance when turned on. Defaults to be turned off, indicating that all the data points will be drawn. Options: 

* 'lttb' Use Largest-Triangle-Three-Bucket algorithm to filter points. It will keep the trends and extremas.
* 'average' Use average value of filter points
* 'max' Use maximum value of filter points
* 'min' Use minimum value of filter points
* 'sum' Use sum of filter points

seriesLayoutBy.desc:
When [dataset][0] is used, seriesLayoutBy specifies whether the column or the row of dataset is mapped to the series, namely, the series is "layout" on columns or rows. Optional values: 

* 'column': by default, the columns of dataset are mapped the series. In this case, each column represents a dimension.
* 'row'：the rows of dataset are mapped to the series. In this case, each row represents a dimension.

Check this [example][1].

[0]: #dataset
[1]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=dataset-series-layout-by

datasetIndex.desc:
If [series.data][0] is not specified, and [dataset][1] exists, the series will use dataset. datasetIndex specifies which dataset will be used.

[0]: #series.data
[1]: #dataset

dataGroupId.desc:
A groupID common to all data in the series. the groupID will be used to classify the data and determine how merge and split animations are performed in the universal transition animation. If you are using the [dataset][0] component to represent the data, it is recommended to use encode.itemGroupID to specify which dimension is encoded as the groupID.

[0]: #dataset

data.value.desc: The value of a single data item.

data.groupId.desc: The groupID of this data item. groupID will be used to classify the data.

data.symbol.desc:
Symbol of single data. Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData

data.symbolSize.desc: single data symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

data.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of single data symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

data.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

data.symbolOffset.desc: Offset of single data symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value. For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

data.label.desc: The style of the text of single data point.

data.label.position.desc:

      // Absolute pixel values
      position: [10, 10],
      // Relative percentage
      position: ['50%', '50%']

data.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

data.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

data.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.color.desc: text color. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }

data.label.rich.<style_name>.borderRadiu.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example: 

* padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
* padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
* padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowOffse.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

data.labelLine.show.desc: Whether to show the label guide line.

data.labelLine.showAbove.desc: Whether to show the label guide line above the corresponding element.

data.labelLine.length2.desc: The length of the second segment of guide line.

data.labelLine.smooth.desc: Whether to smooth the guide line. It defaults to be false and can be set as true or the values from 0 to 1 which indicating the smoothness.

data.labelLine.minTurnAngle.desc: Minimum turn angle between two segments of guide line to prevent unaesthetic display when angle is too small. Can be 0 - 180 degree.

data.labelLine.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color. 

> Supports setting as solid color using > rgb(255,255,255)> , > rgba(255,255,255,1)> , > #fff> , etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [> option.color][0]>  for details 

[0]: #color

data.labelLine.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With dashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    type: [5, 10],
    
    dashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

data.labelLine.lineStyle.dashOffset.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With type , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

data.labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

data.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

data.labelLine.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

Padding of the text fragment, for example: 

* padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
* padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
* padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

data.blur.label.textBorderColor.desc: Storke color of the text. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.blur.label.textBorderWidth.desc: Storke line width of the text.

data.blur.label.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With textBorderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    textBorderType: [5, 10],
    
    textBorderDashOffset: 5
    }

data.blur.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

data.blur.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

data.blur.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

data.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

data.blur.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

data.blur.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

data.blur.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

      position: [10, 10],
      // Relative percentage
      position: ['50%', '50%']

* 'left'
* 'right'
* 'bottom'
* 'inside'
* 'insideLeft'
* 'insideRight'
* 'insideTop'
* 'insideBottom'
* 'insideTopLeft'
* 'insideBottomLeft'
* 'insideTopRight'
* 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position][0].

data.tooltip.desc: tooltip settings in this series data.

data.tooltip.position.desc:
提示框浮层的位置，默认不设置时位置会跟随鼠标的位置。

可选：

* Array

通过数组表示提示框浮层的位置，支持数字设置绝对位置，百分比设置相对位置。

示例:
```javascript
// 绝对位置，相对于容器左侧 10px, 上侧 10 px
position: [10, 10]
// 相对位置，放置在容器正中间
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

* Function

回调函数，格式如下：

```javascript
(point: Array, params: Object|Array.<Object>, dom: HTMLDomElement, rect: Object, size: Object) => Array
```

**参数**
point: 鼠标位置，如 [20, 40]。
params: 同 formatter 的参数相同。
dom: tooltip 的 dom 对象。
rect: 只有鼠标在图形上时有效，是一个用 x , y , width , height四个属性表达的图形包围盒。
size: 包括 dom 的尺寸和 echarts 容器的当前尺寸，例如：{contentSize: [width, height], viewSize: [width, height]}。

**返回值：**
可以是一个表示 tooltip 位置的数组，数组值可以是绝对的像素值，也可以是相 百分比。
也可以是一个对象，如：{left: 10, top: 30}，或者 {right: '20%', bottom: 40}。

如下示例：

```javascript
position: function (point, params, dom, rect, size) {
    // 固定在顶部
    return [point[0], '10%'];
}
```

或者：

```javascript
position: function (pos, params, dom, rect, size) {
    // 鼠标在左侧时 tooltip 显示到右侧，鼠标在右侧时 tooltip 显示到左侧。
    var obj = {top: 60};
    obj[['left', 'right'][+(pos[0] < size.viewSize[0] / 2)]] = 5;
    return obj;
}
```

* 'inside'
    鼠标所在图形的内部中心位置，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

* 'top'
    鼠标所在图形上侧，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

* 'left'
    鼠标所在图形左侧，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

* 'right'
    鼠标所在图形右侧，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

* 'bottom'
    鼠标所在图形底侧，只在 trigger 为 'item' 的时候有效。

data.tooltip.padding.desc:
**> Notice：**> series.data.tooltip only works when [> tooltip.trigger][0]>  is > 'item'> .  
The floating layer of tooltip space around content. The unit is px. Default values for each position are 5. And they can be set to different values with left, right, top, and bottom. Examples: 

    // Set padding to be 5
    padding: 5
    // Set the top and bottom paddings to be 5, and left and right paddings to be 10
    padding: [5, 10]
    // Set each of the four paddings seperately
    padding: [
        5,  // up
        10, // right
        5,  // down
        10, // left
    ]
    



[0]: #tooltip.trigger

data.tooltip.textStyle.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

data.tooltip.textStyle.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

data.tooltip.textStyle.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

data.tooltip.extraCssText.desc:
**> Notice：**> series.data.tooltip only works when [> tooltip.trigger][0]>  is > 'item'> .  
Extra CSS style for floating layer. The following is an example for adding shadow. 

    extraCssText: 'box-shadow: 0 0 3px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3);'
    



[0]: #tooltip.trigger

markPoint.symbol.desc:
Symbol of . Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

If symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format: 

    (value: Array|number, params: Object) => string
    

The first parameter value is the value in [data][1], and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData
[1]: #series-line.data

markPoint.symbolSize.desc:
symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10. If size of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format: 

    (value: Array|number, params: Object) => number|Array
    

The first parameter value is the value in [data][0], and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

[0]: #series-line.data

markPoint.symbolRotate.desc:
Rotate degree of symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle. If rotation of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format: 

    (value: Array|number, params: Object) => number
    

The first parameter value is the value in [data][0], and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item. 

> Callback is supported since 4.8.0 . 

[0]: #series-line.data

markPoint.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markPoint.symbolOffset.desc: Offset of symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value. For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markPoint.silent.desc: Whether to ignore mouse events. Default value is false, for triggering and responding to mouse events.

markPoint.label.position.desc:
Label position. **Followings are the options:*** [x, y] Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example: 

      // Absolute pixel values
      position: [10, 10],
      // Relative percentage
      position: ['50%', '50%']
* 'top'
* 'left'
* 'right'
* 'bottom'
* 'inside'
* 'insideLeft'
* 'insideRight'
* 'insideTop'
* 'insideBottom'
* 'insideTopLeft'
* 'insideBottomLeft'
* 'insideTopRight'
* 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position][0].

markPoint.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

markPoint.label.color.desc: text color. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

markPoint.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }

markPoint.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markPoint.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

markPoint.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

markPoint.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.w.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markPoint.data.symbol.desc:
Symbol of . Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData

markPoint.data.symbolSize.desc: symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

markPoint.data.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

markPoint.data.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markPoint.data.symbolOffset.desc: Offset of symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value. For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markPoint.data.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

markPoint.data.label.lineOverflow.desc:

markPoint.data.label.rich.<style_name>.p.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example: 

* padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
* padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
* padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

markPoint.data.label.rich.<style_name>.s.desc: Shadow color of the text block.
Show blur of the text block.
Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markPoint.data.label.rich.<style_name>.w.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markPoint.data.label.rich.<style_name>.h.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

      position: [10, 10],
      // Relative percentage
      position: ['50%', '50%']
* 'top'
* 'left'
* 'right'
* 'bottom'
* 'inside'
* 'insideLeft'
* 'insideRight'
* 'insideTop'
* 'insideBottom'
* 'insideTopLeft'
* 'insideBottomLeft'
* 'insideTopRight'
* 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position][0].

markPoint.data.emphasis.label.rotate.desc:

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

markLine.symbolSize.desc: Symbol size at the two ends of the mark line. It can be an array for two ends, or assigned seperately. **Attention:** You cannot assgin width and height seperately as normal symbolSize.

markLine.precision.desc: Precision of marking line value, which is useful when displaying average value mark line.

markLine.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be: 

* 'start' starting point of the line.
* 'middle' middle point of the line.
* 'end' ending point of the line.

Since version 4.7.0, more label positions are supported: 'start', 'middle', 'end', 'insideStartTop', 'insideStartBottom', 'insideMiddleTop', 'insideMiddleBottom', 'insideEndTop', 'insideEndBottom'. 'insideMiddleBottom' is the same as 'middle'. Position is as the following chart. The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with [label.distance][0]. 暂时无法显示

[0]: #series-.markLine.label.distance

markLine.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.

* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

markLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

markLine.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

* 'max' maximum value.
* 'average' average value.
* 'median' median value.

markLine.data.0.valueIndex.desc:
Works only when [type][0] is assigned. It is used to state the dimension used to calculate maximum value or minimum value. It may be 0 (for xAxis, or radiusAxis), or 1 (for yAxis, or angleAxis). Dimension of the first numeric axis is used by default.

[0]: #series-line.markLine.data.type

markLine.data.0.valueDim.desc:
Works only when [type][0] is assigned. It is used to state the dimension used to calculate maximum value or minimum value. It may be the direct name of a dimension, like x, or angle for line charts, or open, or close for candlestick charts.

[0]: #series-line.markLine.data.type

markLine.data.0.name.desc: Name of the marker, which will display as a label.

markLine.data.0.x.desc: X position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.0.y.desc: Y position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.0.value.desc: Label value, which can be ignored.

markLine.data.0.symbol.desc:
Symbol of starting point. Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example:

markLine.data.0.symbolSize.desc: starting point symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

markLine.data.0.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of starting point symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

markLine.data.0.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markLine.data.0.symbolOffset.desc: Offset of starting point symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value. For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.desc: Line style of this data item, which will be merged with lineStyle of starting point and ending point.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color. 

> Supports setting as solid color using > rgb(255,255,255)> , > rgba(255,255,255,1)> , > #fff> , etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [> option.color][0]>  for details 

[0]: #color

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With dashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    type: [5, 10],
    
    dashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.dashOffset.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With type , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.curveness.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

markLine.data.0.label.desc: Label of this data item, which will be merged with label of starting point and ending point.

markLine.data.0.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be: 

* 'start' starting point of the line.
* 'middle' middle point of the line.
* 'end' ending point of the line.

Since version 4.7.0, more label positions are supported: 'start', 'middle', 'end', 'insideStartTop', 'insideStartBottom', 'insideMiddleTop', 'insideMiddleBottom', 'insideEndTop', 'insideEndBottom'. 'insideMiddleBottom' is the same as 'middle'. Position is as the following chart. The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with [label.distance][0]. 暂时无法显示

markLine.data.0.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.
